news_summary: Astronomers have successfully measured the mass of a rogue planet drifting through the galaxy, advancing our understanding of these elusive celestial objects.
news_summary_fr: Des astronomes ont réussi à mesurer la masse d'une planète errante dérivant dans la galaxie, faisant ainsi progresser notre compréhension de ces objets célestes insaisissables.
news_summary_es: Los astrónomos han medido con éxito la masa de un planeta rebelde a la deriva a través de la galaxia, avanzando en nuestra comprensión de estos escurridizos objetos celestes.

articles.title: Astronomers measure the mass of a rogue planet drifting through the galaxy
articles.summary: Scientists have discovered a rogue planet roaming the Milky Way after combining observations from Earth and a space telescope. This rare dual perspective allowed them to weigh the planet and pinpoint where it lies in the galaxy. With a mass similar to Saturn, the planet likely formed around a star before being thrown out. The finding opens a new window into how planets are lost to interstellar space.
articles.content:
A new study shows that astronomers have directly measured the mass and distance of a newly discovered free-floating planet by observing it at the same time from Earth and from space. This combined approach made it possible to capture details that are usually missing for these faint objects. The results help explain the many different ways planets can be knocked out of their original systems and sent drifting through interstellar space. So far, only a small number of free-floating planets have been identified, but that number is expected to grow in the coming years. According to Gavin Coleman in a related Perspective, the upcoming NASA Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope campaign, scheduled for launch in 2027, could play a major role. As Coleman notes, "Simultaneous space- and ground-based observations of microlensing events could be applied in the planning of future exploratory missions and could lead to a better understanding of how planets form across the Galaxy."

Most known planets orbit one or more stars, but evidence is mounting that some worlds travel through the galaxy on their own. These lonely objects are known as free-floating or rogue planets, and they have no identified stellar companion. Because they produce very little light, astronomers usually detect them only by watching how their gravity briefly alters the light from a distant background star. This effect is called microlensing. One major challenge with microlensing is that it usually does not reveal how far away the planet is, which makes it hard to calculate its mass independently. As a result, many details about this hidden population of solitary planets have remained uncertain.

In the new research, Subo Dong and colleagues describe the discovery of a free-floating planet spotted during a short microlensing event. What makes this finding unusual is that the event was observed at the same time from Earth and from space. The team used data from several ground-based surveys along with observations from the Gaia space telescope. Small differences in the timing of the light seen from these widely separated locations made it possible to measure the microlensing parallax. When combined with finite-source point-lens modeling, this information allowed the researchers to determine both the planet's mass and where it is located in the galaxy.

The planet has a mass about 22 percent that of Jupiter and lies roughly 3,000 parsecs from the center of the Milky Way. With a mass similar to Saturn, the researchers suggest that it most likely formed within a planetary system rather than developing on its own like a small star or brown dwarf. Scientists think that low-mass rogue planets are born around stars and later forced out of their orbits by gravitational disturbances, such as close encounters with other planets or unstable stellar companions.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific breakthrough in astronomy: the first direct measurement of the mass and distance of a rogue planet using simultaneous Earth- and space-based observations. This discovery advances understanding of planetary formation and dynamics on a galactic scale, with broad implications for astrophysics and future space missions. The story is focused, detailed, and highlights a novel method with potential for expanding knowledge about free-floating planets.
articles.personality_title: Astronomers measure mass of a drifting rogue planet for the first time
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Most planets orbit stars, but some, called rogue or free-floating planets, travel alone through space. These planets are hard to study because they don’t shine and are usually found only by how their gravity bends light from distant stars, an effect known as microlensing.

**What happened** – Scientists recently discovered a rogue planet by observing a microlensing event at the same time from Earth and from the Gaia space telescope. This rare double view let them measure the planet’s mass and distance accurately. The planet, about the size of Saturn, is roughly 3,000 parsecs (about 9,800 light-years) from the center of our galaxy.

**Impact** – This is the first time astronomers have directly measured both the mass and location of a free-floating planet using simultaneous space and ground observations. It proves that these lonely planets likely form around stars and get pushed out by gravitational forces. This method can help find more rogue planets and understand how planets move and change in the galaxy.

**What's next step** – The upcoming NASA Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope, launching in 2027, will use similar methods to find and study more free-floating planets. This will improve knowledge of how many such planets exist and how they behave.

**One-sentence takeaway** – By observing a rogue planet from Earth and space at the same time, astronomers have measured its mass and distance, opening a new way to study lonely planets drifting through our galaxy.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les astronomes mesurent pour la première fois la masse d’une planète errante
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La plupart des planètes tournent autour d’étoiles, mais certaines, appelées planètes errantes ou libres, voyagent seules dans l’espace. Ces planètes sont difficiles à étudier car elles ne brillent pas et sont souvent découvertes seulement grâce à la façon dont leur gravité déforme la lumière d’étoiles lointaines, un phénomène appelé microlentille.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des scientifiques ont récemment découvert une planète errante en observant un événement de microlentille en même temps depuis la Terre et le télescope spatial Gaia. Cette double observation rare leur a permis de mesurer la masse et la distance de la planète avec précision. La planète, de la taille de Saturne, se trouve à environ 3 000 parsecs (environ 9 800 années-lumière) du centre de notre galaxie.

**Impact** – C’est la première fois que des astronomes mesurent directement à la fois la masse et la position d’une planète libre en utilisant des observations simultanées depuis l’espace et la Terre. Cela montre que ces planètes solitaires se forment probablement autour d’étoiles avant d’être éjectées par des forces gravitationnelles. Cette méthode aidera à trouver plus de planètes errantes et à mieux comprendre comment les planètes se déplacent dans la galaxie.

**Prochaine étape** – Le télescope spatial Nancy Grace Roman de la NASA, qui sera lancé en 2027, utilisera des méthodes similaires pour découvrir et étudier davantage de planètes errantes. Cela améliorera la connaissance du nombre de ces planètes et de leur comportement.

**Résumé en une phrase** – En observant une planète errante depuis la Terre et l’espace simultanément, les astronomes ont mesuré sa masse et sa distance, ouvrant une nouvelle voie pour étudier ces planètes solitaires dans notre galaxie.
articles.personality_title_es: Astrónomos miden por primera vez la masa de un planeta errante
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La mayoría de los planetas giran alrededor de estrellas, pero algunos, llamados planetas errantes o libres, viajan solos por el espacio. Estos planetas son difíciles de estudiar porque no brillan y se detectan por cómo su gravedad dobla la luz de estrellas lejanas, un efecto llamado microlente.

**Qué pasó** – Científicos descubrieron recientemente un planeta errante observando un evento de microlente al mismo tiempo desde la Tierra y el telescopio espacial Gaia. Esta rara doble observación les permitió medir con precisión la masa y la distancia del planeta. El planeta, del tamaño de Saturno, está a unos 3,000 parsecs (alrededor de 9,800 años luz) del centro de nuestra galaxia.

**Impacto** – Es la primera vez que los astrónomos miden directamente la masa y ubicación de un planeta libre usando observaciones simultáneas desde el espacio y la Tierra. Esto muestra que estos planetas solitarios probablemente se forman alrededor de estrellas y luego son expulsados por fuerzas gravitacionales. Este método ayudará a encontrar más planetas errantes y a entender cómo se mueven en la galaxia.

**Próximo paso** – El telescopio espacial Nancy Grace Roman de la NASA, que se lanzará en 2027, usará métodos similares para descubrir y estudiar más planetas errantes. Esto mejorará el conocimiento sobre cuántos existen y cómo se comportan.

**Resumen en una frase** – Al observar un planeta errante desde la Tierra y el espacio al mismo tiempo, los astrónomos midieron su masa y distancia, abriendo una nueva forma de estudiar planetas solitarios en nuestra galaxia.
